newsitem.title: RUSSIA: Moscow to stage Russian-Chinese summit next April.
newsitem.headline: Moscow to stage Russian-Chinese summit next April.

text.p: Russian President Boris Yeltsin expects Chinese President Jiang Zemin to visit Moscow in April for a summit that will seal a new level of relations between the two giant states, the Kremlin said on Friday.

Yeltsin's press secretary Sergei Yastrzhembsky told a news briefing the two leaders, together with presidents of the former Soviet republics of Tajikistan, Kazakhstan and Kyrgyzstan would sign an accord reducing forces along their borders.
He gave no details about the timing or extent of troop reductions.
Yastrzhembsky said the timing of Jiang's visit was agreed during a 50-minute meeting between Yeltsin and Chinese Premier Li Peng earlier on Friday.
"Boris Nikolayevich stated that relations between Russia and China have reached a new level," the spokesman said.
China and the former Soviet Union clashed along their border in the 1960s when the two nuclear powers were rivals for the leadership of the world communist movement.
Disputes over border demarcation were for the most part resolved in 1991 and Yastrzhembsky said Yeltsin had promised to finalise the issue next year.
Li was the first foreign visitor to see Yeltsin since his return to work on Monday, following months of illness and a heart bypass operation on November 5.

"It is very good that, out of all states, it was a guest from China who became the first visitor," Yastrzhembsky said, adding that Russian-Chinese relations were expanding and improving at an unprecedented rate.
Russia's desire to develop close links with China has followed NATO's plans to expand eastwards by admitting Moscow's Cold War allies in Eastern Europe as members of the alliance.
Yastrzhembsky said that Yeltsin and Li had agreed that the future political map of the globe should be "a multi-pole world which is not divided into leaders and those who are being led".
Russia also views China as a key trading partner and both countries have shown interest in upgrading economic ties which have failed to keep pace with an improvement in political links.

Li was also due to meet Prime Minister Viktor Chernomyrdin later on Friday. They are expected to arrange to hold regular talks, putting relations on a level that Moscow now has with only the United States and France.

Yeltsin has said more than once that he seeks a strategic partnership between Russia and China. But he has ruled out a revival of the close political and military alliance that had existed between Moscow and Beijing in 1950s.
China and Russia are working on a plan to increase cross-border trade by setting up a special zone in the northeastern Chinese city of Suifenhe that would allow free movement for traders.
The two nations are also negotiating over major deals from nuclear power plants to a natural gas pipeline, but political analysts said Li's visit was unlikely to yield a breakthrough.

Russia has proposed building a pipeline to carry Siberian natural gas to China and is seeking a role in China's huge Three Gorges dam project. It is also keen to sell military and civil aircraft to China.

First Deupty Prime Minister Alexei Bolshakov, quoted by Interfax news agency, said Russia and China planned to sign several documents during Li's visit concerning planned sales of Russia's Su-27 fighters. He gave no details.

Yastrzhembsky said Yeltsin and Li had agreed to aim at bringing annual trade to the volume of $20 billion but he gave no details. Two-way trade was a modest $6.38 billion in the first nine months of this year.
